sentence.text: The patient was a female infant born in the 39th week of gestation via an uneventful vaginal delivery.
Her family had no history of congenital anomalies.
At birth, her head circumference was 33 cm and her body weight was 3,342 g.
Her Apgar score at 5 min was 9.
She had ocular proptosis, a red nevus with skin tags on her forehead, furrowed palms and soles and an umbilical stump (fig. 1aâ€“c).
She also had obstructive respiration, so that her treatment at our newborn infant care unit included intubation.
Since she could not nurse or drink milk from a bottle, she was fed by gastric tube.
Three-dimensional computed tomography at 3 months of age revealed early closures of the coronal, squamous and lambdoid sutures (fig. 2).
MRI at 3 months of age showed exophthalmos, tonsilar herniation, ventricular enlargement and brachycephaly (fig. 3).
At 3 months of age, the patient required a tracheotomy.
She also developed progressive ocular proptosis and ventricular enlargement.
We performed fronto-orbital advancement at 4 months of age and a ventriculoperitoneal shunt procedure at 8 months of age.
Her maxillary bone development was severely disturbed so that she needed a face and head monoblock advancement with LeFort III osteotomy at 20 months of age.
In spite of these treatments, she had severe mental and motor impairment.
